head.title: A Legacy.11 First published in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (March 24, 1796). Though Turnbull’s formal schooling had been cut short, during his later years in Charleston, he supplemented his work for the stage with teaching, and he is listed as “schoolmaster” in the Charleston City Directories for 1809 and 1813.

lg.l: Now, Jook, if I should chance to die,
And leave my hale estate to thee,
’Tis fit that ye should hae a guess
Of what ye shortly may possess;
Lest some ane sue ye for a share,
You, I appoint the lawfu’ heir
Of a’ my silver, goods and gear,
The inventory follows here.
Imprimis22 Latin for firstly; used to introduce a list.--May I lose my noddle,33 n. head.

If I’m possessed of, e’er a bodle44 n. copper coin equivalent to one sixth of an English penny. Cf. Turnbull’s “The Sword” in Poems (1794), pp. 33-34: “’Tis true, I would not plague my noddle / About a rusty useless bodle;” lines 5-6.
In a’ the world, save, halfpence three,
That Jock the student oweth me;
Get if from him by hook or crook.
He ow’st me for a Latin book.
But what will much delight a scholar,
Ye’ll get a ink glass, and a roller,
A pen case of a splu55 n. tobacco-pouch. has made,
A broken knife, that wants the blade,
A pair of specks that want the een,
Yet better specks were never seen:
And likewise, laddie, ye will get
The frame that ance was round a slate,
A cane that’s broken by the middle
The brig and belly of a fiddle
A psalm book, and a bagpipe’s drone,
A mouse trap, and a lexicon;
And what’s of greater value still,
The lid of my auld sneeshing mill!66 n. snuff box (sneezing mull).
Ye’ll get a Hat that once was new,
Though now it’s neither black nor blue,
But just between a grey and brown,
Japann’d wi’ creesh77 n. grease. about the crown;
Item, a glove of ramskin leather,
That coor’d my hands in frosty weather,
A Purse made of a mouse’s skin,
I held, when rich, my silver in—
But hoolie—I had maist neglected
To mention ae thing, much respected—
I mean a Boiler, made of tin,
Runs as fast out as ye’ll fill in:
Such was, as ancient Poets tell,
The lecky bottom’d Tub of hell—88 As punishment for murdering their husbands on their wedding night, the daughters of Danaus were condemned to fill a leaky tub with water drawn from a deep well.
A rusty lock, a three-leg’d stool,
And ae lith of tewa-foot rule,
Twa chair, of great antiquity,
Ten times the age of thee or me;
The tane, indeed, no unco stout,
For aft the bottom tumbles out,
Which gies me mony a weary coup,
And lands me backward on my doup;
On this mysel’ I sometimes lean,
I keep the other for a friend.
If I had any mair to gie,
Nae other man my heir should be:
Sae guide it weel, and I’ll indent ye
Shall never want, while ye hae plenty.
